ContentClassification.TableReference: Ayyar V Sesha, “Mortality of Assured Lives in India, 1970-73 Investigations”, Life Insurance Corporation of India (1974). Reprinted J.R. Joshi and L. P. Venkataraman, “Mortality of Indian Assured Lives”, Economic and Political Weekly, Vol. 15, No. 35 (1980). Accessed: April, 2014 from http://www.jstor.org/stable/4369019
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Life Insurance Corporation of India (LIC) 1970-73. Minimum Age: 20 Maximum Age: 100
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: After nationalization of life insurance business and formation of the Life Insurance Corporation of India, mortality investigations were launched on a regular basis. The first of these studies was for the period 1961-64 (See SOA Table Identity 2744). The second study covers the period of investigation 1970-73 and employed the same method of collection of data as the prior study. As it was believed that some errors crept into the 1961-64 data and the results henceforth deemed less reliable, extra steps were taken with the 1970-73 study to ensure accuracy of the data received in order to avoid omission of deaths. Methodology: There was only adequate data to construct a standard mortality table from the experience of male medically examined lived accepted at ordinary rates under Whole Life and Endowment Assurances; both participating and non-participating basis. Attempts were made to graduate the observed mortality rates by a mathematical formula but a satisfactory fit could not be found. Hence observed rates of mortality were graduated by reference to a Standard Mortality Table, in this case the LIC (1961-64). Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 04/2014

MetaData.TableDescription: Life Insurance Corporation of India (LIC) 1970-73. Minimum Age: 20 Maximum Age: 100
